author: By Billy Witz
title: Since a National Title, Some Very Difficult Days at L.S.U.
description: Louisiana State, which won the College Football Playoff in the 2019 season, followed a 5-5 season by dropping its 2021 opener to U.C.L.A. after evacuating because of Hurricane Ida.
content: PASADENA, Calif. — Max Johnson, Louisiana State’s sophomore quarterback, backpedaled several steps as he felt the heat of the U.C.L.A. pass rush. When that maneuver didn’t buy him enough time, he pivoted and began to run backward until, with another Bruins defender closing in, he realized that was a bad idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Guzdar
title: What Happened the Day After I Was Sexually Harassed at the Pentagon
description: When I arrived at the office, the reality that awaited me was the one I’d never imagined: the best-case scenario.
content: I was an intern at the Department of Defense attending an office happy hour in July when a drunken senior employee — a man much older than me — began trailing me. He followed me, along with other interns, as we moved from group to group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Emma Goldberg
title: Some Americans ignore warnings against using ivermectin to treat Covid.
description: Clinical trials have repeatedly failed to show that the drug is effective against the virus. Still, U.S. demand is high.
content: Public health warnings against using the anti-parasitic ivermectin as a treatment for Covid-19, especially in the large doses meant for livestock, appear to have made little progress in stemming its popularity in parts of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: S.A. Cosby, a Writer of Violent Noirs, Claims the Rural South as His Own
description: After years of small breaks, Cosby has found big success with “Blacktop Wasteland” and “Razorblade Tears,” propulsive books about family, sex, race, class and the stain of Southern history.
content: SHACKLEFORDS, Va. — The J. K. Redmond Funeral Home is a low-slung brick building in this small town in southern coastal Virginia. It’s owned by Kimberly Redmond Cosby, the wife of the crime writer S. A. Cosby. He still puts in hours there, though fewer since his crime novels began to appear on national best-seller lists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: U.S. Citizens and Afghans Wait for Evacuation Flights From Country’s North
description: The Taliban have left hundreds of people stranded in Afghanistan awaiting approval for departure.
content: Around 1,000 people, including dozens of American citizens and Afghans holding visas to the United States or other countries, remained stuck in Afghanistan for the fifth day on Sunday as they awaited clearance for the departure from the Taliban. The holdup reflects the challenges of foreign governments working with the group, which has yet to form a government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: From ‘Ku Kluxism’ to Trumpism
description: Many of the Klan’s tactics are still being used to preserve white supremacy and subjugate racial, ethnic and religious minorities in United States.
content: One hundred years ago this week, The New York World began to publish a 21-part explosive exposé on the inner workings of the Ku Klux Klan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
title: Covid Deaths Surge Across a Weary America as a Once-Hopeful Summer Ends
description: Cases are starting to fall in some hard-hit Southern states, but nearly half of Americans are not fully vaccinated, allowing the Delta variant to persist.
content: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — A summer that began with plunging caseloads and real hope that the worst of Covid-19 had passed is ending with soaring death counts, full hospitals and a bitter realization that the coronavirus is going to remain a fact of American life for the foreseeable future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: At U.S. Open, Carlos Alcaraz Is Ready for the Spotlight
description: After the teenager from Spain stunned Stefanos Tsitsipas, he said he has dreamed of playing on “the best court in the world” for much of his 18 years. Now he’s won on it.
content: The coming-of-age party and fifth-set tiebreaker were over on Friday night. Carlos Alcaraz, an 18-year-old Spaniard, had finally finished throwing towels into the Arthur Ashe Stadium stands after his U.S. Open upset of Stefanos Tsitsipas. One by one or in small groups, the fans walked up the stairs toward the exits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: The First Afghan Rhodes Scholar Saved Her Father, and Wants to Do More
description: Summia Tora used her connections to get her father and an uncle on a flight out of Kabul. Helping other Afghan refugees, she said, may occupy “most of the rest of my life.”
content: OXFORD, England — Five days after the Taliban captured Kabul, Summia Tora began to fear that her father would never get out of Afghanistan. She had been up almost round-the-clock, working every angle to get him on an evacuation flight. But without a special immigrant visa, he did not get a call from American officials offering a coveted seat on a military plane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katy Reckdahl, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Sophie Kasakove
title: New Orleans Power Failure Traps Older Residents in Homes
description: “I had to get out of there,” said one 86-year-old man who sat in his eighth-floor apartment for nearly a week after Hurricane Ida, struggling to breathe without his medical equipment.
content: NEW ORLEANS — For five days after Hurricane Ida tore through New Orleans and left the city in darkness, 86-year-old Eddie Gentry sat in his sweltering, eighth-floor apartment, fearing that he was running out of breath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: At U.S. Open, Barbora Krejcikova Makes the Most of Finally Making It
description: When Open qualifying was canceled in 2020, the Czech player who was outside the top 100 doubled down on her game, fitness and work ethic. Now she’s a top 10 player and in the final 16.
content: Barbora Krejcikova missed out on last year’s U.S. Open when the qualifying draw was canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic. Instead, she played small tournaments in her native Czech Republic in hopes that she might earn enough ranking points to move closer to her goal of breaking into the WTA top 100 singles rankings for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Military Analysis Raises Questions About Deadly Drone Strike in Kabul
description: A preliminary analysis said that it was “possible to probable” that explosives were in the car and that drone operators took only a cursory scan of the courtyard before launching an attack.
content: WASHINGTON — The U.S. military’s top officer asserted last week that a drone attack on a sedan near the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, was a “righteous strike” that foiled a plot by the Islamic State in the waning hours of the immense evacuation effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: A new study of dorm rooms shows how ventilation curbs virus levels.
description: The study of infected students at an isolation dorm suggests that opening a window could reduce the amount of coronavirus in a room by half.
content: Opening a window could reduce the amount of coronavirus in a room by half, according to a new observational study of infected college students in an isolation dormitory at the University of Oregon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: A Skeleton for Diplomacy: How a Plan to Reconcile France and Russia Collapsed
description: The remains of a Napoleonic general who died on a Russian battlefield came home in July. But the chance for rapprochement collapsed over concerns about Moscow’s policies.
content: LE BOURGET, France — The plan, to repatriate the skeleton of a Napoleonic general who died on a Russian battlefield two centuries ago, was supposed to bring together the leaders of two nations long at odds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gwen Knapp
title: ‘Inspiration Porn’: Paralympians Know It When They See It
description: Athletes reject the idea that they should be admired just for coping with disabilities, and not also for what they’ve accomplished.
content: TOKYO — Darlene Hunter, a three-time Paralympian and a college professor, begins her classes on disability issues exploring what may be the most provocative phrase ever associated with an international sports event: “inspiration porn.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Eric Lipton
title: Crypto Banking and Decentralized Finance, Explained
description: The revolution in digital money is now moving into banking, as cryptocurrency starts to reshape the way people borrow and save.
content: The development of Bitcoin and thousands of other cryptocurrencies in a little over a decade has changed the definition of money — and spawned a parallel universe of alternative financial services, allowing crypto businesses to move into traditional banking territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerome Karabel
title: Let’s Honor the True Spirit of Labor Day
description: The labor movement’s often bloody struggle for human dignity is  neglected in standard accounts of American history.
content: In the late summer of 1921, an epic but surprisingly little-known confrontation took place between the forces of labor and capital. The battle unfolded not in one of the great industrial cities but in the rural coal country of southern West Virginia. Miners in the region — angered by life-threatening working conditions, corporate domination of the grim company towns in which they lived, the violent suppression of their attempts at unionization and the murder of a pro-labor local sheriff by company-hired thugs — took up arms to confront the coal companies in what became known as the Battle of Blair Mountain. It was the largest labor uprising in American history and the biggest armed uprising in the United States since the Civil War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: In Hong Kong, Jimmy Lai’s Media Company Moves to Close Down
description: Next Digital, which has published criticism of China for decades, said a crackdown had left it with no way to operate. Its main newspaper, Apple Daily, closed in June.
content: HONG KONG — Next Digital, a Hong Kong media company that has published vehement criticism of the Chinese government for decades, said on Sunday that it would take steps to shut down after an official crackdown had left it with no way to operate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: The Next Act for Marcel the Shell (and Jenny Slate)
description: The internet’s favorite mollusk is the subject of a new film. In the process of making it, she realized, “I was doing something that actually was very personal.”
content: TELLURIDE, Colo. — Jenny Slate is at a loss for words. It’s Friday night at the Telluride Film Festival and the actress has just deplaned from her first flight in 17 months, still foggy from quarantine, a period when she became the mother of two distinct but equally profound projects: a brand-new baby girl and a feature-length movie she spent a decade creating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yubelka Mendoza, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Alfonso Flores Bermúdez
title: ‘Everyone Is on the List’: Fear Grips Nicaragua as It Veers to Dictatorship
description: A crackdown on opposition by President Daniel Ortega leaves Nicaraguans to wonder: Who is next?
content: MANAGUA, Nicaragua — The nights were the hardest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: The Best Birthday Present in 2021? A Covid Vaccine.
description: Turning 12 has taken on added significance this summer, as tweens line up for shots allowing them to see friends and play sports again.
content: Zoe Tu, a seventh grader in Brooklyn, likes to celebrate her birthday with dulce de leche Haagen-Dazs ice cream cake. This year, her 12th, was no exception, but the day was also marked by a treat of another kind: her Covid vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Sunday
description: Barbora Krejcikova and Garbiñe Muguruza meet in a battle of players ranked in the top 10 in the world. Canada’s Felix Auger-Aliassime plays Frances Tiafoe.
content: How to watch: From noon to 6 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN, 7 to 11 p.m. on ESPN2, and streaming on the ESPN app. In Canada, on TSN from 11 a.m. to 11 p.m., and streaming on TSN.ca and the TSN app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Brazil-Argentina Match Stopped After Health Officials Storm Field
description: After a disagreement about quarantine rules, a high-profile match was interrupted by government officials seeking to deport four Argentine players.
content: A World Cup qualification game between Brazil and Argentina, South America’s most successful soccer teams, was halted after only a few minutes on Sunday after Brazilian health authorities walked onto the field during play as part of an effort to deport four Argentine players accused of violating coronavirus quarantine regulations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Thailand protests Covid-19 failures.
content: Demonstrations against the government’s bungled response to the pandemic have become a daily event, and crackdowns are growing more aggressive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katy Reckdahl and Bryan Tarnowski
title: On Grand Isle, a Fragile Spot Off Louisiana, Vast Damage
description: A tiny barrier island already endangered by sea level rise was pounded by Hurricane Ida. Most buildings were significantly damaged, many irreparably.
content: GRAND ISLE, La. — As Hurricane Ida blew in last Sunday, Scooter Resweber, the local police chief, gathered his 10 officers into his second-story corner office, where he believed they would be most safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: New Orleans Goes Dark
description: Hurricane Ida raised the question of how well energy companies are prepared for extreme weather.
content: Hurricane Ida made landfall on Sunday, leaving more than a million residential and commercial customers in Louisiana without power. And the outages raise questions about how well energy companies have prepared for extreme weather, which scientists believe is becoming more common because of climate change. Some energy experts said that Entergy, the state’s largest utility company, could have done more to protect its equipment. Last year, the company began operating a natural gas plant that was meant to provide electricity to New Orleans during times of high demand or in emergencies. But it could not move the energy to customers because of damage to its network of towers, poles and wires. It has asked state regulators to raise customers’ rates to cover repair costs for Ida, three hurricanes in 2020 and a winter storm this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: ‘You Can Be Defeated’: An Ultramarathoner Deals With Failure
description: Scott Jurek set out to reclaim the supported speed record for the roughly 2,200-mile Appalachian Trail. He had his own reality check.
content: There are still four months to go in 2021, but it’s safe to say that this will go down as the year when many supposedly superhuman sports stars finally decided it was OK to admit they are human after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Alyssa Lukpat
title: Ex-Marine Sharpshooter Kills 4 and Fires at Deputies in Florida, Sheriff Says
description: The gunman, a veteran of the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, fatally shot a man, two women and an infant inside two homes near Lakeland, Fla., the authorities said. A girl, 11, was wounded.
content: A former Marine sharpshooter who served in Afghanistan and Iraq fatally shot four people, including an infant, in two homes near Lakeland, Fla., early on Sunday morning and exchanged gunfire with sheriff’s deputies before he was taken into custody, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and Ephrat Livni
title: Crypto’s Rapid Move Into Banking Elicits Alarm in Washington
description: The boom in companies offering cryptocurrency loans and high-yield deposit accounts is disrupting the banking industry and leaving regulators scrambling to catch up.
content: BlockFi, a fast-growing financial start-up whose headquarters in Jersey City are across the Hudson River from Wall Street, aspires to be the JPMorgan Chase of cryptocurrency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Corrigan
title: How to Let Go of Your Irreplaceable, Unstoppable Daughter
description: My child’s path has split from mine, as it should. But maybe the best is yet to come.
content: My 18-year-old daughter appears in the kitchen in a Ruth Bader Ginsburg sweatshirt, makes a mug of Rice Krispies treats in the microwave and shows me a photo on her phone of two sloths hugging. That’s Claire. Like yours, she’s one of a kind. Like yours, she’s irreplaceable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Back on the Trail, Sanders Campaigns for a Legislative Legacy
description: Senator Bernie Sanders is barnstorming the country again, but not for the presidency. Instead, he’s making the case for a $3.5 trillion bill that would be a once-in-a-generation achievement.
content: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — With a khaki-clad leg propped up on a bench, hand on his hip, Senator Bernie Sanders was regaling the post-church Sunday brunch crowd outside a bar with enticing details about Democrats’ emerging $3.5 trillion budget bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: At the U.S. Open, No. 1 Ashleigh Barty Is Stunned by Shelby Rogers
description: The American beat Barty, who had won five tournaments this year including Wimbledon, 6-2, 1-6, 7-6 (5). Rogers made the crowd work for her.
content: Shelby Rogers held an unusual distinction when she walked onto the court in Arthur Ashe Stadium on Saturday. She was the last remaining American woman in the U.S. Open women’s singles draw, and it was only the third round.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: On the Up-and-Up
description: Joshua Rosenblatt makes a (fashion) statement.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — In 2019, there were 32 constructors who made their New York Times Crossword debuts. In 2020, this more than doubled to 64 new constructors. And with today’s debut by Joshua Rosenblatt, we have 58 debuts for 2021, with nearly four months left to go in the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Extreme Weather, Bitcoin, Spring Gardening: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: The Met Opera Reunites, With Mahler’s ‘Resurrection’
description: After a year and a half, the company’s forces came together for an outdoor performance of the sprawling, ecstatic symphony.
content: The Metropolitan Opera hardly ever plays concerts at home at Lincoln Center. But before Saturday evening, the company had opened its season with Mahler’s Symphony No. 2, the “Resurrection,” once before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damon Winter and Binyamin Appelbaum
title: The Power in Numbers
description: Workers across the U.S. are finding new ways to organize and exercise power, even in the face of corporations determined to undermine unions.
content: In early September 1921, the federal government dispatched thousands of troops and 15 fighter planes to Logan County, W.Va., to assist in the violent suppression of thousands of coal miners seeking the right to unionize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: The Secret to Yebba’s Debut Album? A Big Voice and Lots of Time.
description: The 26-year-old singer and songwriter endured a family tragedy on the journey between tasting viral success and assembling a complete artistic vision with Mark Ronson.
content: The singer and songwriter Yebba has a story she tells about the moment she realized she was fated to pursue a career in music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: N.F.L. Will Allow Six Social Justice Messages on Players’ Helmets
description: The decals, with messages such as “Stop Hate” and “Black Lives Matter,” are part of the league’s efforts to show solidarity with players who have protested against racism and police brutality.
content: The N.F.L. will allow players to display messages of social justice on their helmets and will stencil the slogans “It Takes All of Us” and “End Racism” on the end zones at every field as part of an effort to show solidarity with the protest movements against racism and police brutality, league officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: Biden to Visit Northeast Flood Zones as Demand Grows for Climate Action
description: The president will visit hard-hit areas in New York and New Jersey, as residents call for more serious action on climate change.
content: As residents scrambled to clean up and assess damage from catastrophic flash floods that swept the Northeast last week, President Biden prepared to visit hard-hit areas in New York and New Jersey, where he will confront political ferment that is growing over the climate-driven disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muktita Suhartono and Hannah Beech
title: Thai Protesters Are Back, and Angrier, as Government Fumbles on Covid
description: With more than 12,000 dead, few vaccinated and the economy in shambles, demonstrations against the authorities have become a daily event.
content: BANGKOK — In air heavy with monsoonal pressure and discontent, the riot police in Bangkok unleashed rubber bullets and tear gas. Tanat Thanakitamnuay, the scion of a real estate family, stood on a truck, where he had been excoriating Thailand’s leaders for their bungled response to the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: We Should All Be a Little More Like Dorothy Day
description: A labor activist and devout Catholic, she had a unique vision for a better world.
content: I caught my friend Heath Carter, an associate professor at Princeton Theological Seminary, breathless. He’s training for a half marathon and picked up my call just after a sprint. I asked if I could talk to him about a hero of mine, the Catholic social activist Dorothy Day, and her involvement with the labor movement. Soon, Heath was another kind of breathless, absorbed, as good professors get, in the complexities presented to us by this remarkable woman, her witness, her contradictions, the controversies and passions of her life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Kentucky governor says the state’s Covid surge is ‘dire.’
description: Kentucky recorded a seven-day average of 4,423 new daily cases on Saturday, according to a Times database.
content: Kentucky’s Democratic governor on Sunday described the state’s surge of Covid cases as “dire,” and pointed out that Republican state lawmakers had limited his options to control the record wave of infections there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Maggie Nelson Exposes Freedom’s Paradoxes
description: The poet and critic’s latest book, “On Freedom,” is a philosophical meditation on a concept at the center of American history and culture.
content: ON FREEDOMFour Songs of Care and ConstraintBy Maggie Nelson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Michaux
title: Patrick Cantlay Wins the FedEx Cup
description: Cantlay fended off Jon Rahm, the world No. 1, at the Tour Championship in Atlanta to claim the $15 million prize.
content: ATLANTA — Given a head start, Patrick Cantlay proved uncatchable at the season-ending Tour Championship.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘When I Got to the Museum, I Was Told I Could Not Check My Luggage’
description: Making an emergency stop, ode to a first lipstick and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: How the Texas Anti-Abortion Movement Helped Enact a Near-Complete Ban
description: Texans are almost evenly divided on abortion, but a combination of Republican control, conservative judicial appointments and cultural shifts helped the state’s anti-abortion movement find success.
content: RICHARDSON, Texas — A steady stream of women trickled into Prestonwood Pregnancy Center late last week, alone and with partners, with appointments and without. One couple held hands and whispered cheerfully; a young woman scrolled through her phone until her name was called. A wall-mounted screen in a corner cycled through a carousel of inspirational messages. “You are strong.” “Hope is stronger than fear.” “There are options.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdourahmane Diallo, Ruth Maclean and Mady Camara
title: Special Forces Colonel Says He Has ‘Seized’ Guinea’s President
description: If the coup is successful, it will mark the third time in five months that a West African nation has suffered a takeover.
content: CONAKRY, Guinea — Heavy gunfire echoed around the capital of Guinea early on Sunday morning. Then pictures surfaced on social media of the West African country’s president being held in custody by men in military fatigues. Finally, the head of Guinea’s special forces announced on state television that the constitution, government and all institutions were dissolved. He had staged a coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: How’s Hollywood to Plan When It Doesn’t Know Who’s Watching What?
description: With box office numbers way down in the pandemic and streaming numbers hard to come by, the film industry is often unable to determine whether a movie is a hit or a miss.
content: LOS ANGELES — Labor Day Weekend is typically a moment for Hollywood to take a breath and assess. After the big-budget escapism of summer and before the Oscar hopefuls of fall, what signals are moviegoers sending?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: How a Small Town Silenced a Neo-Nazi Hate Campaign
description: A Montana town reflects on its effort to drive former President Donald J. Trump’s extremist supporters back to the fringes.
content: WHITEFISH, Mont. — Richard B. Spencer, the most infamous summer resident in this town, once boasted that he stood at the vanguard of a white nationalist movement emboldened by President Donald J. Trump. Things have changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Lawyer Is Shot Months After Unsolved Killing of His Wife and Son
description: Alex Murdaugh, the descendant of a prominent family of lawyers in rural South Carolina, was shot on Saturday, nearly three months after his wife and son were killed at their home.
content: For nearly three months, the question of who killed the wife and son of Alex Murdaugh, a prominent lawyer in rural South Carolina, has gripped the state’s Lowcountry region as harrowing details of the crime emerged but the police made no arrests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Is 9/11 a Day, or Is It an Era?
description: After 20 years, it’s time for TV to treat Sept. 11 as serious, even divisive history, not just dutiful remembrance.
content: The TV specials for the Sept. 11 anniversary offer any number of ways to return to hell. There are wrenching interviews with survivors and with those whose loved ones died; uplifting stories of rescues and agonizing stories of those who perished in the attempt; footage of the conflagration, chaos and shock, as seen on morning newscasts and in the ash-blanketed streets; images of the first responders and volunteers digging through wreckage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Daniel Politi and Flávia Milhorance
title: Covid Ravaged South America. Then Came a Sharp Drop in Infections.
description: South America was the epicenter of the Covid-19 pandemic early this year. Experts are trying to find out why new infections and deaths are falling so fast.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Just a few weeks ago, Covid-19 was spreading with alarming ease across a cluster of nations in South America, overwhelming hospital systems and killing thousands of people daily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Thai Protesters Condemn Lagging Government Covid Response
description: Protesters in Bangkok threw fake blood and hung mock corpses, as they demanded the resignation of Thailand’s prime minister. More than 12,000 people have died of Covid this year and few have been vaccinated.
content: Protesters in Bangkok threw fake blood and hung mock corpses, as they demanded the resignation of Thailand’s prime minister. More than 12,000 people have died of Covid this year and few have been vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Ida Leaves Wreckage on a Fragile Barrier Island in Louisiana
description: Homeowners surveyed the destruction in Grand Isle, La., where hundreds of buildings were destroyed by Hurricane Ida.
content: Homeowners surveyed the destruction in Grand Isle, La., where hundreds of buildings were destroyed by Hurricane Ida.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 5, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 5, 2021.
content: A cover article this weekend about students at the State University of New York who have been taken to court over tuition debt refers incorrectly to the disposition of lawsuits brought by New York’s attorney general against students. While there were an average of 2,500 default judgments every year from 2017 through 2019, the judgments in a given year were not necessarily from lawsuits that were filed the same year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Plan to make a no-recipe feast of spaghetti and clams, or any of our newest recipes.
content: Good morning. Greetings from the middle of a strange holiday weekend. It was meant to be, for some of us, the end not just of unofficial summer but of many of the protocols meant to keep us safe from the coronavirus — a time to return to commuting, perhaps to an office, to the rhythms of what passed for normal life back in 2019. Until it wasn’t. We’re still masking, still anxious about breakthroughs, still unsure what’s going to happen with the children’s schooling, still worried about the future, still unsettled in the present.
source.name: The New York Times

title: My Cat’s Watching Me. What’s She Thinking?
description: Readers discuss the relationship between cats and humans. Also: Tech companies and child exploitation; hospital billing; the minimum wage.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
